entry.title: SAP Sustainability Control Tower: Q2 2025 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the first half of 2025, global sustainability governance has entered a new phase of scrutiny and recalibration. The EU Omnibus amendments to the CSRD have postponed timelines and reduced the scope of immediate obligations for thousands of companies, temporarily easing the pressure of compliance. However, this regulatory pause has only sharpened the spotlight on data integrity, preparedness, and strategic ESG integration. 

At the same time, investors, regulators, and civil society are intensifying their expectations. Public disclosures are no longer judged on completeness alone—they must be audit-ready, aligned with recognized frameworks like ESRS and EU Taxonomy. Companies are expected to move beyond box-ticking compliance into continuous ESG performance management, proactively steering their sustainability journey. 

SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) is designed precisely for this challenge. It enables organizations to: 

  • Record ESG factors with out-of-the-box integration to SAP systems and trusted third-party sources 
  • Analyze performance across financial, operational, and sustainability dimensions to support informed decisions 
  • Accelerate the transition through auditable, framework-aligned reporting—covering both regulatory and voluntary disclosures, powered by AI 

Building on our momentum from Q1, this quarter's updates focus on strengthening ESRS-aligned metric coverage, deeper analytical flexibility, improved auditability, and tighter alignment with financial structures. 

 

Expansion of SAP-provided metric coverage   

To support organizations on their ESRS compliance journey, SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) continues to expand its library of SAP-provided metrics aligned with the European Sustainability Reporting Standards. These include both qualitative and quantitative definitions based on EFRAG's implementation guidance. Current metric coverage is available in the SAP Help Portal and detailed in the SAP Community blog, offering transparency and reuse for accelerated implementation.  

 

Looking ahead, we plan to reach approximately 80% coverage of ESRS data points by the end of 2025, including metrics from ESRS 2, S2–S4, G1, and additional quantitative metrics from ESRS Topical Standards. This roadmap aims to enable our customers to progressively adopt SCT content for structured, auditable, and regulation-ready ESG disclosures while maintaining flexibility to extend for sector-specific or company-specific needs. 

 

Analyze ESG Data App Enhancements 

The Analyze ESG Data application now offers a significantly improved analytics experience with the introduction of the Analytics tab. Users can explore all standard custom quantitative metrics in greater depth by applying drill-down dimensions, choosing between chart or table formats, and configuring default views tailored to reporting needs. This new flexibility allows up to three charts to be displayed simultaneously, each with independent metric, period, and structure settings. 

In parallel, users can manage and switch between saved configurations of grouped metric tiles (“Overviews”), enabling different perspectives for different stakeholders or strategic priorities. Together, these enhancements empower users to personalize and streamline how ESG data is analyzed, viewed, and shared – supporting more informed decision-making and stronger alignment with sustainability goals. Find full details here: Using the Analyze ESG Data Application.

 

Custom Templates for “Generate ESG Reports with AI” App 

The Generate ESG Reports with AI app now offers greater flexibility and control through the introduction of custom templates. Users can create or edit templates to tailor the structure and content of ESG reports using available SAP-provided quantitative metrics.  

Within the Templates section, you can now select “Create” to build a new template or modify an existing one by adding sections and subsections, defining narrative text, and selecting from a predefined list of charts and tables. For each component, a content preview is available to ensure alignment with the selected reporting period. Once finalized, templates can be saved and reused, enabling consistent and structured ESG reporting across time periods.  

When generating a report, you can preview or download the result as a PDF—and for added customization, you can edit any section manually. SAP's built-in AI-assistance now supports dynamic revisions: simply select a passage and use the “Revise” option to receive suggestions to shorten or lengthen the text, helping refine your final ESG narrative with ease and speed. 

 

Fiscal Period Support 

The new Manage Fiscal Year Variants app brings flexible fiscal period support to SAP Sustainability Control Tower, allowing customers to define and activate custom fiscal year variants that align with their internal planning cycles. Whether using standard calendar months or granular date-based periods (like semi-monthly ranges), organizations can now tailor their ESG data analysis and reporting across key apps such as Analyze ESG Data, Manage GHG Data, and View Emission Dashboard. Built-in validation checks help ensure data compatibility, with options to consolidate or reimport data when switching to a new variant. This enables more accurate reporting, tighter alignment with financial periods, and greater control over how sustainability data is structured and interpreted across the organization. 

 

Change log updates 

In Q2, we've significantly improved transparency and traceability across SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT). Users can now track create, update, and delete changes to public overview configurations in the Analyze ESG Data app using the View Change Logs app. This functionality extends further, providing detailed logs for changes in business activity data, clearly showing the number of updated or imported records and distinguishing between actual and target data. 

 

New Languages Supported 

To better serve global enterprises, SAP SCT now supports Turkish and Italian languages. This update enables local teams to work in their native languages and enhances cross-regional collaboration on sustainability data collection and reporting. 

 

H2 2025 Roadmap Updates 

Looking ahead, we’re focused on simplifying and harmonizing ESG data consumption and reporting. A key milestone will be the delivery of a unified Read API for metric values – supporting both quantitative and qualitative data – to  make calculated ESG metrics easily accessible to external tools like disclosure management platforms. This API will also expose key metadata (including ESG standard references) and allow for both bulk and individual metric retrieval based on reporting scopes. We’re also working on improving flexibility in data modeling by enabling custom account groups, account-to-group mappings, and supporting activity data input through multiple channels. Additionally, we’ll continue expanding metric-level analysis, measure drilldowns, and export formats in the Analyze ESG data application. To enhance data quality and reporting alignment, we’re introducing tools for guiding data requirements based on double materiality, setting up reporting hierarchies and data sources, and improving transparency on data completeness. In parallel, we aim to deliver ESRS-aligned metric definitions that cover up to 70% of EFRAG's guidance, along with clear documentation and community updates to keep you informed as mentioned above. Stay tuned: SCT Roadmap Explorer. 

 

Additional Information 

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Control Tower, we recommend browsing the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release.

entry.title: Transforming User Experience: SAP Fiori Launchpad adopts the latest SAP Design System updates
entry.content:
Overview

The SAP Fiori launchpad now incorporates the latest SAP Design System, bringing improvements to the shell bar and navigation area, user menu and notifications. These enhancements are designed to unify and streamline the user experience, ensuring the interface is more intuitive and consistent across SAP's portfolio, in alignment with our Suite First strategy.

 

Feature release outlook

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

This feature is available with 2508. Parts of it will be offered as opt-in (refer to the  SAP KBA and SAP Note).

For further information refer to the official documentation here.

  • SAP BTP ABAP Environment

This feature is available with 2508 (only when spaces and pages are enabled).

For further information refer to the official documentation here.

  • SAP Integrated Business Planning

This feature is available with 2508.

For further information refer to the official documentation here.

 

Key Highlights

Shell Bar 

A key update is the repositioning of the navigation menu. It is now prominently located at the top of the shell bar, enabling users to access the navigation menu swiftly and efficiently.

Before and After:

  • Before: The navigation menu was designed to support the personalization of spaces.
  • After: The functionality has been enhanced, and the navigation menu now offers seamless access to navigation.

Additionally, for SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud and SAP BTP ABAP environment the shell bar now supports displaying the product name alongside the company or brand logo. Administrators can manage and translate the product name using the WINDOW_TITLE_EXTENSION parameter located in the Manage Launchpad Settings app, e.g. refer to Manage Launchpad Settings | SAP Help Portal for SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud Edition.

Before and After:

  • Before: The product name could not be included in the shell bar.
  • After: The product name is now configurable and can be displayed in the shell bar next to the company or brand logo. Likewise, the browser window title, the product name next to the logo and the app title are now synchronized. 

                                                                                                   

 

Navigation menu

 

 

The navigation can now be accessed using the navigation menu. If the My Home space is configured, you will see the Favorites Apps section .(For SAP S/4HANA My Home space is in sync with the Favorites). Following this, you'll find the My Spaces section. In this section, you can view all your personalized spaces and pages.

If the SPACES_NAVIGATION_BAR_PERSONALIZATION setting is enabled in the Manage Launchpad Settings app, you'll see the All Spaces option, which allows for personalization of spaces (pinning and unpinning spaces).

 Before and After:

  • Before: The navigation menu had a different position in the shell bar, providing options for personalizing spaces.
  • After: The most significant advantage of the navigation is that it allows you to directly access entries from within any application, eliminating the need to return to the home page first.

User Menu

The user menu has been updated from a simple popover with a list to a more visually appealing design. The entries have been reordered according to new UXC guidelines, placing ‘Settings’ at the top. The menu now can display an avatar, user's ID or the e-mail address depending on configuration options in the different products or platforms. Previously, the sign-out option was a standard list item located at the end of the list. It has now been relocated to the footer of the user menu.

Before and After:

  • Before: The user menu previously was a basic list items menu.
  • After: The user menu has been redesigned to provide a more intuitive user experience.

Notifications

 

Earlier, notifications could be grouped by Date, Type, and Priority. Considering recent usage data that indicated minimal use of the "By Type" option, the UI has been simplified by eliminating this grouping. Notifications can now be sorted using a sort of button, with options to arrange them by date or by importance.

Moreover, while in the notifications view, users can easily navigate to notification settings in the user menu by using the Settings icon in the upper-right corner.

Before and After:

  • Before: Previously, notifications were grouped by Date, Type, or Priority.
  • After: Notifications are now organized by date or importance, with direct access to settings via the Settings  icon.

Conclusion

With the adoption of the latest SAP Design System we strive to empower users to navigate and use SAP applications with greater ease and efficiency.

entry.title: Transport Management in SAP Cloud ERP 3SL Architecture During Upgrades
entry.content:
Introduction

In SAP Cloud ERP's 3-system landscape (3SL) architecture, transport management becomes particularly complex during release upgrades. This Blogpost provides comprehensive guidance on managing transports when systems are at different release levels, addressing common challenges and best practices.

Understanding the 3SL Upgrade Timeline

In the standard three-system landscape, the test system is upgraded three weeks before the development and production systems during each release cycle. This approach provides sufficient time for regression testing before upgrading the remaining systems

Transport Types in SAP Cloud ERP

Before examining specific scenarios, it's essential to understand the three primary transport types:

  •  Customizing Transports: Generated because of Configuration changes via Central Business Configuration or Implementation activities Application.
  •  Developer Extensibility Transports: Created when any kind of ABAP developers extensions created generally via ABAP development tool.
  •  Key User Extensibility Transports: Created as a result of Key user extensions for example Custom field and logic, Custom business objects etc.

Transport Management Scenarios

Scenario 1: Uniform Release Level (N-N-N)

When development, test, and production systems operate at the same release level, transport management follows the standard process:

  • Export all transport types from the development system
  • Import transports into the test system
  • Forward transports to the production system
  • Complete the process by importing into the production system

Scenario 2: Mixed Release Levels (N-N+1-N)

This scenario occurs during the upgrade window when the test system operates at a higher release level than development and production systems.

For Customizing and Developer Extensibility Transports

The standard transport process from Scenario 1 remains applicable.

For Key User Extensibility Transports

Certain objects face import restrictions into higher release systems. For example, SAP Fiori Launchpad Pages (UIPC) during 2502 release (reference: 3560509 - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502 in a 3-system landscape: Release Restriction Note - SAP for Me).

Transports which contain these kinds of objects are shown as outdated. And we have two options for managing them:

Option A: Forward Without Import

Forward the transport from the test system without importing it, and then import it into the productive system

Option B: Re-export After Alignment

After all systems have been upgraded to the same level, you have to re-export the same content again from the development system and transport to test and production system, so as to ensure that the key user extensibility is also in the test system.

Thank you for reading this blog post, hopefully, the blog post was informative and helped you to understand in detail how to manage Transports during upgrade.

Note: You can't import a transport created on release n into release n+2 and higher, which means that you have to recreate the transport in the development system. However, it is not possible to recreate CBC transports. In this case, you have to create a support incident.

Note: To identify the objects not supported for N,N+1 Transports For 2508 Release, Please read the Release Note that generally released 2 Weeks before the T system upgrade.

entry.title: Settlement of Investment Projects in SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
What is Project Settlement?

Settlement is the process of transferring costs incurred on a project to a final receiver such as:

  • an asset under construction
  • a completed fixed asset
  • or a cost object (e.g. cost center)

In the context of capital investment projects, this ensures the capital expenditures (CapEx) are properly posted to the balance sheet instead of the P&L.

To start with a simplified view, we can split the complete process into two parts:

Asset Creation Phase

  • settlement moves costs from the investment project to asset(s) under construction

  • this can be done via periodic settlement at the close of the period or event-based with every posting to the investment project

Final Asset available to be used

  • settlement moves balance sheet values from asset(s) under construction to final asset 
    values that cannot be capitalised can be moved to other cost objects, e.g. cost centers

  • this is done via periodic settlement at the close of the period

 

Master Data Involved

Investment Projects are used primarily for planning and monitoring capital investments that are not capitalised directly, due to their scope or the large percentage of in-house production involved.

  • All expenditures related to the investment project are tracked separately to differentiate them from regular operational costs.
    This can include materials, labor, and overheads.
  • The account assignment object for actual posting is always the investment project/ WBS element.
  • Investment projects are relevant for asset accounting this is why they have an asset under construction (AuC) assigned.

Assets Under Construction refer to the work-in-progress phase where a company is finalising the development or acquisition of long-term assets (like a building or a piece of machinery).

  • Costs related to the asset under construction are recorded in an asset under construction/ capital work-in-process account on the balance sheet. This account accumulates all expenditures until the asset is ready for its intended use.
  • The asset under construction is included in the asset history sheet and keeps detailed records of all costs related to investment projects for audit and regulatory purposes.
  • Once the construction is completed and the asset is ready for use, the total accumulated costs in the asset under construction account are transferred to the appropriate fixed asset account on the balance sheet.

 

Lifecycle of the Investment Project

SAP provides standard capabilities to manage the entire lifecycle of an investment project:

  1. Project Creation
    initiated via the app Project Control - Enterprise Projects
  2. Cost Collection
    Costs from procurement, time recording, and service are collected on the investment project WBS (work breakdown structure) elements
  3. Asset Under Construction (AuC) Creation
    Automatically created when the project is released. Make sure you are using the project profile Investment Project.
  4. Periodic or Event-Based Settlement
    Periodic jobs can be scheduled via the app Schedule Overhead Accounting Jobs. For processing of single investment projects, you can use Run Settlement – Actual.
    With release CE2508 a new functionality Event-based Settlement to AuC is available. Using event-based settlement makes the periodic settlement process obsolete as all costs are settled immediately when posted to the investment project.
  5. Final Settlement and Asset Capitalisation
    Upon project completion, costs are settled to the final fixed asset. Costs that cannot be capitalised can be settled to other cost objects (e.g. cost centers).

 

How Project Settlement Works

1. Settlement to Asset under Construction (AuC)
  • periodic settlement: with the first settlement the rule to AuC gets automatically created (settlement type AUC)
    PRE rules can be used to make sure non-capitalisable costs are not posted to the AuC.
  • event-based settlement: 100% of the costs will be settled to AuC, rules for preliminary settlement (PRE rules) are not supported, no AUC settlement rule is needed.
    Event-based settlement is a new functionality made available with CE2508. It can be activated in the investment profile (for details on configuration see dedicated chapter).

2. Settlement to Final Asset

When the project is completed and the asset can be used, the AuC is cleared and costs are capitalised to the final asset.

  • The status of the investment project will be changed to technically completed. With this status the system carries out full settlement (distribution rules of type “full settlement” are used)
  • in the event-based scenario the final settlement will post to final receiver per line item, enabling the feature “list of origins reporting” for the AuC and the final asset
  • the processing type “partial capitalisation” can be used for a partial settlement to fixed asset/ other cost object, before the investment project is technically completed.

 

Settlement Rules

Define the receivers which could be AuC, final asset, or other cost objects.
Rules can be defined as percentages/ equivalences or amounts. Each rule comes with a validity period.

  • Full Settlement (FUL)
    • all costs posted to the sender, also costs in prior periods are settled
    • ensures a balance of zero even if late postings to prior period occur
    • these rules are used for final settlements to the fixed asset,
      or they can be used for partial capitalisation if values shall be moved out of the asset under construction before the asset is finished
  • Preliminary Settlement (PRE)
    PRE rules are used during settlement to AuC (preliminary settlement), if part of the costs shall not be activated on AuC
    > not available with event-based settlement
  • Settlement to AuC (AUC)
    with periodic settlement these rules are automatically created with the first settlement, the receiver is the AuC

Examples for different settlement/ distribution rules:

line 1 shows a rule for settlement from AuC to cost object that can be used with processing type “Partial Capitalisation”
such rules need to be valid for one period only (from/to = identical)

line 2 +3 show rules for settlement to fixed asset (final settlement)

line 4 shows a rule for settlement to AuC (preliminary settlement)
> not supported with event-based settlement

 

Period End Closing - Settlement Run

 

Event Based Settlement (new CE2508)

 

Ledger Specific Settlement Rules

  •  Ledger-Specific Settlement                                                 
    • values to be settled will be calculated per ledger 
    • always active in SAP Cloud ERP  
  • Ledger-Specific Settlement Rules
    • settlement rules can be defined per ledger
    • optional, needs to be activated in settlement profile

Possible Use Case
Settlements to assets under construction/ final asset shall be done according to different GAAPs, e.g. German GAAP defines that 70% of construction costs can be activated while US-GAAP allows for activation of 80% of construction costs.

 

Key Configuration Elements

  • Project Profile
    Project profiles are pre-delivered in the public cloud edition and cannot be configured. make sure you are using profile Investment Project to enable the integration to asset management
  • Settlement Profile
    Determines whether the settlement is allowed and to which receiver type.
  • Asset Class & Number Ranges
    Defines the type of asset created (e.g. building, machinery).
  • Investment Profile
    Used to configure the asset class for the asset under construction. You can also define if you want to have just one AuC created per WBS element, or if you need several AuC for one WBS element.
    The option for event-based settlement is also activated in the investment profile.

 

Benefits of Project Settlement in SAP Cloud ERP

  • Transparency: Clearly track investment costs and their capitalisation status
  • Automation: Reduce manual tasks with predefined rules and scheduled jobs
  • Compliance: Aligns with IFRS and local GAAP requirements
  • Audit Readiness: Comprehensive documentation of all postings and asset movements

Additional Benefits with Event-Based Settlements

  • Transparency: with event-based settlement postings are moved line item by line item throughout the complete settlement process from the project to the AuC and to the final asset.
  • Automation: as the first settlement step “Project 2 AuC” is done event-based, no manual interaction or job scheduling is needed any longer
  • Compliance: the line item details will still be available for the final asset. With this level of detail it is very easy to explain the asset value as for each posting can navigated back to the initial project posting. This kind of reporting is even available without using line item settlement.

entry.title: Display Changes to Objects
entry.content:
This analytical application lets you review the recorded field changes for an object.

Screen Areas

Information filter

You can use the information filter at the top of the screen to select which data is displayed in the chart and table. This allows you to view recorded field changes for objects in various ways. You must enter the Object and Time Interval, as they are mandatory filters. Additionally, you can use other filters, such as "Object Component" and "Changed By", among others.

Fig. 2: Filter bar

Visual filter

Visual filter provides a graphical interface for interacting with and filtering your data. It allows you to view and filter the frequency of Changes to Fields based on "Change Type", "Year and Calendar Week" as well as by "Object Component" such as Item or Schedule Line.

Fig. 3: Visual filter bar

Bar chart

The bar chart offers a concise overview of the frequency of specific change fields. By selecting a bar, you can filter the entries in the table. Additionally, utilize the View By filter to explore different dimensional data. You also have the option to change the chart type from the default bar chart for other kinds of charts.

Fig. 4: Bar chart in Hybrid view

Fig. 5: Bar chart in Chart-only view

The "Hybrid view," also referred to as "Chart and Table View," is the default setting that displays both the chart and the table simultaneously. Additionally, you have the option to toggle between "Chart-only view" and "Table-only view" within the chart area.

Fig. 6: Toolbar in chart area

Table

The table located at the bottom of the screen provides additional details regarding the logged changes to objects, including Change Field, Change Type, Object IDs, Changed By, Old Value, and New Value. In the "Settings" button, you have the option to customize the displayed columns to include information such as Object Keys, Activity ID, Source of Data, and more. Additionally, you can utilize the "Group By" and "Sort by" features for the columns.

Fig. 7: Table in Table-only view

Upon clicking on column "Object IDs" you will be directed to the details page of the Fiori app "Display Business Events by Business Object".

Fig. 8: Details page of Display Business Events by Business Object

Upon clicking on each row in the "Change Type" column, you are directly directed to the event details page (Fiori app "Display Business Event Logs"),  or a dialog popover appears, displaying concise event information.

Fig. 9: Event Type and Versions in a Dialog

Upon selecting a table entry, you will be directed to the details page of the Fiori app "Display Business Event Logs".

Fig. 10: Details page of Display Business Event Logs

SAP S/4 HANA (On-Premise)2025 FPS0 and later
